did.unittitle: Robert Schulman collection of materials related to Romany Marie
did.abstract: Robert Schulman had a 70-year journalism career that encompassed print and broadcast reporting, writing, and commentary in three different regions of the country. The collection contains typescript of the book "Romany Marie, Queen of Greenwich Village", a transcript of an interview with Romany Marie, correspondence, articles, clippings, a music score, and photographs. There is also a small amount of biographical information about Schulman.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Robert Schulman had a 70-year journalism career that encompassed print and broadcast reporting, writing, and commentary in three different regions of the country. Born in New York, he was a graduate of New York University and the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism. He served in the U.S. Air Corps and Air Transport Command from 1942-46 and began his newspaper reporting career in St. Louis in 1937. Much later, Mr. Schulman published "Romany Marie: The Queen of Greenwich Village" in 2006. He died in 2008 at the age of 91.

Romany Marie, nee Marie Marchand, was a Greenwich Village doyenne and restaurateur who played a key role in bohemianism in New York City from the early 1900s through the late 1950s. Her cafes and tearooms, more akin to salons, were warm and lively places, known for the dynamic interchange and pollination of ideas that took place there. They had an extensive following, especially among artists and literati, including Buckminster Fuller, Eugene O'Neill, Mary Garden, Muriel Draper, and sculptors Isamu Noguchi and David Smith. Romany Marie, who has been described as attractive and unusual, lively and generous, was a well known and beloved character who provided free meals to those who needed them. She was a former anarchist who had attended Emma Goldman meetings, although she later distanced herself from anarchism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains research files and related documents pertaining to the book "Romany Marie, Queen of Greenwich Village" by Robert Schulman. Includes typescript of the book, a transcript of an interview with Romany Marie, correspondence, articles, clippings, a music score, and photographs. There is also a small amount of biographical information about Schulman.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: To the extent that she owns copyright, Louise T. Schulman has retained copyright in her works donated to Smith College. Copyright in other items in this collection may be held by their respective creators. For reproductions of materials that are governed by fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required. For those few instances beyond fair use, or which may regard materials in the collection not created by Louise T. Schulman, researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights and obtaining approval from them. Researchers do not need anything further from Smith College Special Collections to move forward with their use.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: As a preservation measure, researchers must use digital copies of audiovisual materials in this collection. Please consult with Special Collections staff to request the creation of and access to digital copies.
